text: In a bustling medical center, healthcare professionals specializing in Family Medicine and Gastroenterology are dedicated to providing top-notch care to their patients. The Family Medicine department focuses on overall health and wellness, treating a wide range of conditions, while the Gastroenterology department specializes in digestive system disorders and ailments. One common health issue that often overlaps between these two departments is Diabetes Mellitus, a metabolic disorder that affects blood sugar levels. Patients with Diabetes Mellitus may require management from both Family Medicine and Gastroenterology specialists to address the various aspects of their condition. In order to better understand the relationship between these medical specialties, a causal analysis is needed to determine if there is at least one common effect of both Gastroenterology and Family Medicine. Can we identify such a common effect in the treatment and care of patients with Diabetes Mellitus?
Q: Examine the potential existence of a shared consequence as a collider for Gastroenterology and Family Medicine.

Q: Analyze the presence of a common outcome serving as a collider for Gentamicin and Cardiac Catheterization.

text:

One of the common conditions he encounters is Cataract, a clouding of the eye's natural lens, often related to aging. Additionally, Dr. Jenkins has a number of patients suffering from Arthritis, an inflammation of the joints causing pain and disability. Some of these patients also seem to have various conditions such as Septicemia, a serious bloodstream infection that can lead to sepsis, and Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), a chronic inflammation of the digestive tract, often associated with abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, and weight loss. Dr. Jenkins noticed that some of his patients suffering from IBD also tend to have Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS), a larger, chronic disorder that affects the large intestine and commonly causes cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea and constipation. 

Now, Dr. Jenkins is intrigued and wants to dig deeper to find any possible relations between these conditions, specifically Arthritis and Vertigo. So, he sets out to perform causal analysis on the available data. In relation to this, he wants to answer one key question: "Whether there exists at least one collider (i.e., common effect) of Arthritis and Vertigo?"
Q: Assess the existence of at least one common effect (collider) between Arthritis and Vertigo.
